Var, let and const

... About 5 min

# Var, let and const

# What's the difference?

A lot of shiny new features came with ES2015 (ES6), and it's assumed that a lot of JavaScript developers have become familiar with and have started using these features. While this assumption might be true, it's still possible that some of these features remain a mystery to some.

One of the features that came with ES6 is addition ofÂ letÂ andÂ constÂ which can be used for variable declaration. The question now is, what makes them different from our good ol'Â varÂ which has been in use? If you are still not clear about this, this article is for you.

In this article,Â var,Â letÂ andÂ constÂ will be discussed with respect to their scope, use and hoisting. As you read, take note of the differences between them I'll point out.

# VAR

Before the advent of ES6,Â varÂ declarations ruled as King. There are issues associated with variables declared withÂ varÂ though. That is why it was necessary for new ways to declare variables to emerge. First though, let us get to understandÂ varÂ more before we discuss one of such issues.

Scope ofÂ var

ScopeÂ essentially means where these variables are available for use.Â varÂ declarations are globally scoped or function/locally scoped. It is globally scoped when aÂ varÂ variable is declared outside a function. This means that any variable that is declared withÂ varÂ outside a function block is available for use in the whole window.Â varÂ is function scoped when it is declared within a function. This means that it is available and can be accessed only within that function.
To understand further, look at the example below.

    var greeter = "hey hi";

    function newFunction() {
        var hello = "hello";
    }

Here,Â greeterÂ is globally scoped because it exists outside a function whileÂ helloÂ is function scoped. So we cannot access the variableÂ helloÂ outside of a function. So if we do this:

    var tester = "hey hi";

    function newFunction() {
        var hello = "hello";
    }
    console.log(hello); // error: hello is not defined

We'll get an error which is as a result ofÂ helloÂ not being available outside the function.

varÂ variables can be re-declared and updated

That means that we can do this within the same scope and won't get an error.

    var greeter = "hey hi";
    var greeter = "say Hello instead";

and this also

    var greeter = "hey hi";
    greeter = "say Hello instead";

# Hoisting

Hoisting is a JavaScript mechanism where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope before code execution. What this means is that if we do this:

    console.log (greeter);
    var greeter = "say hello"

it is interpreted as this

    var greeter;
    console.log(greeter); //greeter is undefined
    greeter = "say hello"

SoÂ varÂ variables are hoisted to the top of its scope and initialized with a value of undefined.

Problem withÂ var

There's a weakness that comes withÂ var. I'll use the example below to explain this.

    var greeter = "hey hi";
    var times = 4;

    if (times > 3) {
        var greeter = "say Hello instead";
    }

    console.log(greeter) //"say Hello instead"

So, sinceÂ times > 3Â returns true,Â greeterÂ is redefined toÂ "say Hello instead". While this is not a problem if you knowingly wantÂ greeterÂ to be redefined, it becomes a problem when you do not realize that a variableÂ greeterÂ has already been defined before.
If you have useÂ greeterÂ in other parts of your code, you might be surprised at the output you might get. This might cause a lot of bugs in your code. This is why theÂ letÂ andÂ constÂ is necessary.

# LET

letÂ is preferred for variable declaration now. It's no surprise as it comes as an improvement to theÂ varÂ declarations. It also solves this problem that was raised in the last subheading. Let's consider why this is so.

letÂ is block scoped

A block is chunk of code bounded by {}. A block lives in curly braces. Anything within curly braces is a block. So a variable declared in a block with theÂ letÂ is only available for use within that block. Let me explain this with an example.

   let greeting = "say Hi";
   let times = 4;

   if (times > 3) {
        let hello = "say Hello instead";
        console.log(hello);//"say Hello instead"
    }
   console.log(hello) // hello is not defined

We see that usingÂ helloÂ outside its block(the curly braces where it was defined) returns an error. This is becauseÂ letÂ variables are block scoped .

letÂ can be updated but not re-declared.

Just likeÂ var, a variable declared withÂ letÂ can be updated within its scope. Unlikevar, aÂ letÂ variable cannot be re-declared within its scope. So while this will work,

    let greeting = "say Hi";
    greeting = "say Hello instead";

this will return an error.

    let greeting = "say Hi";
    let greeting = "say Hello instead";//error: Identifier 'greeting' has already been declared

However, if the same variable is defined in different scopes, there will be no error.

    let greeting = "say Hi";
    if (true) {
        let greeting = "say Hello instead";
        console.log(greeting);//"say Hello instead"
    }
    console.log(greeting);//"say Hi"

Why is there no error? This is because both instances are treated as different variables since they have different scopes.

This fact makesÂ letÂ a better choice thanÂ var. When usingÂ let, you don't have to bother if you have used a name for a variable before as a variable exists only within its scope. Also, since a variable cannot be declared more than once within a scope, then the problem discussed earlier that occurs withÂ varÂ does not occur.

Hoisting ofÂ let
Just likeÂ var,Â letÂ declarations are hoisted to the top. UnlikeÂ varÂ which is initialized asÂ undefined, theÂ letÂ keyword is not initialized. So if you try to use aÂ letÂ variable before declaration, you'll get aÂ Reference Error.

# CONST

Variables declared with theÂ constÂ maintain constant values.Â constÂ declarations share some similarities withÂ letÂ declarations.

constÂ declarations are block scoped

LikeÂ letÂ declarations,Â constÂ declarations can only be accessed within the block it was declared.

constÂ cannot be updated or re-declared

This means that the value of a variable declared withÂ constÂ remains the same within its scope. It cannot be updated or re-declared. So if we declare a variable withÂ const, we can neither do this

    const greeting = "say Hi";
    greeting = "say Hello instead";//error : Assignment to constant variable.

nor this

    const greeting = "say Hi";
    const greeting = "say Hello instead";//error : Identifier 'greeting' has already been declared

Every const declaration therefore, must be initialized at the time of declaration.
This behavior is somehow different when it comes to objects declared withÂ const. While aÂ constÂ object cannot be updated, the properties of this objects can be updated. Therefore, if we declare aÂ constÂ object as this

    const greeting = {
        message : "say Hi",
        times : 4
    }

while we cannot do this

    const greeting = {
        words : "Hello",
        number : "five"
    }//error :  Assignment to constant variable.

we can do this

    greeting.message = "say Hello instead";

This will update the value ofÂ greeting.messageÂ without returning errors.

Hoisting ofÂ const

Just likeÂ let,Â constÂ declarations are hoisted to the top but are not initialized.

So just in case, you missed the differences, here they are :

  1. varÂ declarations are globally scoped or function scoped whileÂ letÂ andÂ constÂ are block scoped.

  2. varÂ variables can be updated and re-declared within its scope;Â letÂ variables can be updated but not re-declared;Â constÂ variables can neither be updated nor re-declared.

  3. They are all hoisted to the top of their scope but whileÂ varvariables are initialized withÂ undefined,Â letÂ andÂ constÂ variables are not initialized.

  4. WhileÂ varÂ andÂ letÂ can be declared without being initialized,Â constÂ must be initialized during declaration.
